data.text: Buying a Bike Pump: Small, Lightweight, with Pressure Gauge.

Looking for bike pump recommendations, any tips? The pump should be: - small/ light enough to attach to the frame - have a pressure gauge (important for the gravel bike imo) - ideally with a short tube to save the rims - should be able to at least go up to 65 PSI - durable Thanks!
Following. Good question
data.author: Luca Basanisi

data.text:
This is what I use. Mine has a pressure gauge. There are a few different versions. https://ride.lezyne.com/products/1-mp-mfdr-v204hv
MICRO FLOOR DRIVE HV
ride.lezyne.com
data.author: Douglas Miner

data.text: , can support that. I also have the one with pressure gauge and it works well even for large tires.
data.author: Sandro Georgi

data.text: great pump, highly recommend it. Although Id buy it without the gauge. Mine stopped working after a couple of trips. And it's not really needed, you can judge the pressure easily enough with your hand.
data.author: David Butterly

data.text: I've thought about that. When pumping my tires and thinking "oh this looks good, 65 PSI" and I check, it's around 40 or 50 PSI, so I have zero intuition for it that's why I feel it's important to have (for me)
data.author: Ahmd Lim

data.text: I'd recommend a digital gauge if you need that info. I can run pressure between 12 and 50 psi, always know when I ride if pressure needs to be changed.
data.author: David Butterly

data.text: i have 2 and bought one for my son too. Great pump!
data.author: Al Christensen

data.text: I have the pressure gauge on mine but I never use it. I look at the tires while riding and push on them with my thumb.
data.author: Douglas Miner

data.text:
I personally like the Topeak RaceRocket. It's small, lightweight, has decent volume for it's size and has a built-in hose to screw onto your valve stem to stop any unintentional stress on the presta valve from pumping. https://www.topeak.com/global/en/products/216-Mini-Pumps/333-RACEROCKET
RACEROCKET®
topeak.com
data.author: Brian Stewart

data.text: +1. Can't see the point in a pressure gauge for a "mobile" pump.
data.author: Adrian Smith

data.text: I also carry a Topeak D2 pressure gauge when bikepacking, but not for normal rides.
data.author: Brian Stewart

data.text: Bought a high volume Specialized that’s about 9” long and 1.5” wide. It’s the best I’ve found after being perpetually disappointed with most of them. No pressure gauge though. I’d just focus on usability and reliability and not worry about the gauge. Your narrowing your options by 90% and they’re all gadgets and have suspect reliability
data.author: Robert Taylor

data.text:
Topeak has one that fits all of those specifications. I don’t have it, but I was scoping it out before: https://www.topeak.com/global/en/products/216-Mini-Pumps/432-SHOCK-‘N-ROLL
SHOCK ‘N ROLL
topeak.com
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text:
What kind of tires (high volume or high pressure - guessing high volume) Here is a great small pump that meets every requirement https://ride.lezyne.com/products/1-mp-mfdr-v204hv
MICRO FLOOR DRIVE HV
ride.lezyne.com
data.author: Larry Narachi

data.text: Lezyne Alloy Drive high volume (medium) + tiny Schwalbe Airmax pressure gauge pump is compact, with minimum moving parts, highly reliable and field serviceable
data.author: Aleksandr Geižān

data.text:
Several versions of the Topeak "morph" series of pumps check all your boxes. I've used the original "road morph" one for 20+ yrs (among others), it's a nice compromise between full road/frame pump and mini (million stroke) pumps. https://www.topeak.com/global/en/products/216-Mini-Pumps
Mini Pumps
topeak.com
data.author: Doug McLerran

data.text: I had turbo morph for touring. Would not recommend. The system for clamping onto the valve was very unreliable, and the foot peg and pressure gauge both broke within a few months; reviews from other customers suggest this is a common problem. Odd, because my topeak picket rocket is brilliant and very well made
data.author: Richard Andrew

data.text: I like my crank brothers klic hv gauge.
data.author: Leif Warner

data.text: Lezyne pocket drive hv is the one I carry and I have a wall full of mini pumps 😁
data.author: Jerry Duford

data.text: Crank Brothers Click pump with the built in CO2 head is heavier than others but is the best best I've used.
data.author: Bob Eiserman

data.text: Picked up a Bontrager Mini-Charger recently and have been pretty happy with it.
data.author: Dave Henderson

data.text: Silca Tattico with Bluetooth gauge.
data.author: Scott Hawn

data.text: Topeak Road Morph Pump with Gauge
data.author: Scott Bass

data.text: I bought a Crank Brothers Klic and the hose won't thread onto some Presta valves and won't seal on others. (I tried a variety of Conti and Scwalbe.) Their customer service never got back to me. Most unfortunate as they look great on paper.
data.author: Samuel Chapman

data.text:
Pro Bike Tool Mini Bike Pump with... https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00XLGKU14?ref=ppx_pop_mob_ap_share
PRO BIKE TOOL Bike Pump with Gauge Fits Presta and Schrader - Accurate Inflation - Mini Bicycle Tire Pump for Road, Mountain and BMX Bikes, High Pressure 100 PSI, Includes Mount Kit
amazon.com
data.author: Chris Mayfield
